clean_story:
"Unsolvable mazes. Daedalus built them. "

The name Daedalus means "cunning worker"—a craftsman who designed labyrinths so complex, even their creator barely escaped.

Most know the labyrinth as a prison for the Minotaur, but its real genius was psychological warfare.

Daedalus didn’t just build walls—he exploited human panic.

His designs used repetitive patterns (like a spiral with deceptive dead-ends) to make victims doubt their memory.

Imagine walking the same path three times, convinced you’re lost—when the exit was always just left of the second turn.

The Cretan Labyrinth (his most famous) had no high walls—just low hedges, forcing the Minotaur to rely on sound and scent to hunt.

Daedalus’s trick? Asymmetry: one path looked identical to another but led to the center—or a pit.

His own escape proved the design’s flaw: he flew over it.

Three related subjects are maze-solving algorithms, ancient trap architecture, and spatial disorientation tricks.
